Course Description: Knowledge Graphs (semantic descriptions of entities and their relationships) are heavily used in knowledge enabled applications across several domains such as life science, geoscience, healthcare, Internet of Things, smart cities etc. Commercial enterprises such as Google, Microsoft, Amazon, LinkedIn, IBM, GE, Siemens, Accenture, etc., use knowledge graphs in several of their applications. Ontologies encode knowledge of a domain in a machine processable form and act as the schema for the data in the knowledge graphs. In this course, we will learn how to design ontologies to capture domain knowledge and use them to power intelligent applications.

Prerequisites.Mandatory: CSE102 Data Structures & CSE 201 Advanced Programming

Course Outcomes.CO1: Students are able to design and construct ontologies with concepts (20-30), roles (5-10), and relationships between them.
Course Outcomes.CO2: Students are able to demonstrate the utility of ontologies by using it in an application

Weekly Lecture Plan.Lecture Topic: Introduction to course content What is an Ontology? What is OWL (Web Ontology Language)?
Steps in designing an ontology Introduce Protege, and some of its plugins
Describe an in-class modeling exercise & build an ontology List some sample domains for students to work on. Student groups can pick one of these (or others of their choice) and work on them
Introduce ontology reasoning and reasoners Introduce OWL API
Introduce Ontology Design Patterns (ODPs) Redesign the in-class ontology using ODPs
Discuss project progress Validating ontology, unit testing Anti-patterns
Lifecycle of an ontology, ontology maintanance, version control Open problems in ontology modeling
